messages.text:
Is there a shorter way to write `for m₁ in axes(M, 1), m₂ in axes(M, 2)` in the code below? m₁ and m₂ are required.
```let M = [1 2 3; 4 5 6]
	res = Any[]
	for m₁ in axes(M, 1), m₂ in axes(M, 2)
		push!(res, (M[m₁, m₂]))
	end
	res
end```

elements.text: Is there a shorter way to write
for m₁ in axes(M, 1), m₂ in axes(M, 2)
in the code below? m₁ and m₂ are required.

let M = [1 2 3; 4 5 6]
	res = Any[]
	for m₁ in axes(M, 1), m₂ in axes(M, 2)
		push!(res, (M[m₁, m₂]))
	end
	res
end

messages.text:
I need some help with handling missing data in DataFrames.
Let’s say I have a DataFrame with a column of text, some of whose values are missing, and a function that operates on that text.

`f(s) = isnothing(match(r"ext", s)) ? "" : s[2:end]`

`df = DataFrame(:a=>["text", missing, "more text"], :b=>rand(3))`

I want to get back a DataFrame with column :a modified to contain the results of f(s) where it is not missing.
Should be easy-peasy but I  can’t figure out the syntax from the DataFrames documentation.

Any ideas?

elements.text:
I need some help with handling missing data in DataFrames.

df = DataFrame(:a=>["text", missing, "more text"], :b=>rand(3))

I want to get back a DataFrame with column :a modified to contain the results of f(s) where it is not missing.
Should be easy-peasy but I  can’t figure out the syntax from the DataFrames documentation.

Any ideas?

messages.text:
The LinearAlgebra.jl package's `inv()` function does not preserve matrix symmetry.
```while true
    R = randn((3,3))
    R[2,1] = R[1,2]; R[3,1] = R[1,3]; R[2,3]=R[3,2]
    @assert R == R'
    @assert inv(R) == inv(R)'
end```
I'm about to open an issue for this, but in the meantime: is there a way to deal with this?

elements.text: The LinearAlgebra.jl package's
inv()
function does not preserve matrix symmetry.
I'm about to open an issue for this, but in the meantime: is there a way to deal with this?

messages.text:
Hello everyone!
I am trying to select element 3, 4, 7 and 8 in a DataFrame called dm.y.
If I call "dm.y[1:8]" I get all the elements and if I call dm.y[3:4] I get element 3 and 4.

Is there a call similar to "dm.y[3:4 7:8]" to only get the ones I want?
Or do I need to do two different calls and then merge the results?

elements.text:
Hello everyone!
I am trying to select element 3, 4, 7 and 8 in a DataFrame called dm.y.
If I call "dm.y[1:8]" I get all the elements and if I call dm.y[3:4] I get element 3 and 4.

Is there a call similar to "dm.y[3:4 7:8]" to only get the ones I want?
Or do I need to do two different calls and then merge the results?

messages.text:
If I have the following struct:
```mutable struct FactorF{V,C,T} # variables, cardinality, array type
  vals::T
end```
and I have an instance of `Factor` where `T` happens to be `Array{Float64,3}`, what is the proper way to access the `Float64` ? Here is an example of an approach I found:
```import Base: eltype
eltype(::FactorF{V,C,T}) where {V,C,T} = T.parameters[1]

A = FactorF{(1,2,3), (3,3,3), Array{Float64,3}}(rand(3,3,3))
eltype(A) |> println # prints Float64```
Is this the proper way to do this?

messages.text:
Hey everyone!
I'm having some trouble with structs and am stuck here :disappointed:

I have some code of the following nature:

```struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)```

Now, I want to add a boolean arguement to the struct. I added a 'neighbors' parameter and came up with this:


```struct BlockPartition{Dim,T, neighbors = false} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
  neighbors::Bool
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors}(sides, neighbors)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition(sides, neighbors)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
  Dim = embeddim(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
  calculate_metadata = method.neighbors```

However it doesn't seem to be working. I suspect the problem lies in the following lines:


`BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)`

`BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)`

However I am not sure how to change them. How can I go about doing this?
I get the following error:

elements.text:
Hey everyone!
I'm having some trouble with structs and am stuck here
I have some code of the following nature:

struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
Now, I want to add a boolean arguement to the struct. I added a 'neighbors' parameter and came up with this:

struct BlockPartition{Dim,T, neighbors = false} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
  neighbors::Bool
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors}(sides, neighbors)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition(sides, neighbors)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
  Dim = embeddim(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
  calculate_metadata = method.neighbors
However it doesn't seem to be working. I suspect the problem lies in the following lines:
BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)
BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

However I am not sure how to change them. How can I go about doing this?
I get the following error:

messages.text:
Hi all. I have a function in which I create an array but the type of the array is selected by the user meaning that it is passed as an argument something like:
```function f(T)
    arr = Matrix{T}(undef,3,3)
    return arr
end```
What is a correct type-stable way to do this? This is basically the function to load a bunch of data into named tuples with pre-specified types for each tuple element (I cannot use DataFrames).

elements.text: Hi all. I have a function in which I create an array but the type of the array is selected by the user meaning that it is passed as an argument something like:

function f(T)
    arr = Matrix{T}(undef,3,3)
    return arr
end
What is a correct type-stable way to do this? This is basically the function to load a bunch of data into named tuples with pre-specified types for each tuple element (I cannot use DataFrames).

messages.text:
I have a function where I would like to move something from runtime to compile-time. It looks similar to this
```function foo(x::Int, y::Val{Z}) where Z
    table = calc_table(Z)
    bar(table, x)
end```
I would like to move the `calc_table` to compile time, since the computation only depends on compile time constants. But the table allocates an array, filling it in, before converting it the returned tuple. I think somehow the allocation means the code is not side-effect free, and so the compiler will not move it to compile time.
How can I tell the compiler "you can consider this a pure function, just go ahead and constant fold it"?

elements.text: I have a function where I would like to move something from runtime to compile-time. It looks similar to this

function foo(x::Int, y::Val{Z}) where Z
    table = calc_table(Z)
    bar(table, x)
end
I would like to move the
calc_table

to compile time, since the computation only depends on compile time constants. But the table allocates an array, filling it in, before converting it the returned tuple. I think somehow the allocation means the code is not side-effect free, and so the compiler will not move it to compile time.
How can I tell the compiler "you can consider this a pure function, just go ahead and constant fold it"?

messages.text:
Are the gains from this <#C6A044SQH|helpdesk> bot really worth it? When I expressed that I thought it was obnoxious, the reaction was essentially, "I don't give a @&$%"

Some people agreed. Some people disagreed. I know it bothers me enough that I've distanced myself from Slack because of it (and, to a certain extent, Julia generally and my evangelism for the language for that matter). 

Are the gains worth alienating people like me who may admittedly be in the minority?

messages.text:
Hi! I am trying to write a generic version of a function that takes a parametric type and constructs that type with a _different_ parameter. In more detail, my type hierarchy is roughly:
```abstract type MySupertype{T} end

struct MyType1{T} <: MySupertype{T}
    field::T
end

struct MyType2{T} <: MySupertype{T}
    field::T
end```
I realize the notation here doesn't work, but I want to do something like:
```function my_fn(x::MT{T}) where MT{T} <: MySupertype{T} where T
    return ForwardDiff.gradient(p -> MT(p...), [0.])
end```
Is this possible, or do I need to write a different version of the function for the two possible values of `MT`? Thanks so much!

messages.text:
Let's say I have a function that takes `N` 2x2 arrays of floats. How can I perform broadcast multiplication on all `N` arrays? I tried something like:
```N = 3
arrays = [rand(2,2) for _ in 1:N]
reduce(.*, arrays)```
but `.*` is not defined.

N
2x2 arrays of floats. How can I perform broadcast multiplication on all
N

N = 3
arrays = [rand(2,2) for _ in 1:N]
reduce(.*, arrays)
but
is not defined.
Does anyone know how to solve a network of SDE ?

messages.text: This message was deleted.

Hi. Why does this function not work when different UInts are passed?
```isunsigned(x::T, y::T) where {T <: Unsigned} = (x isa Unsigned) && (y isa Unsigned)
isunsigned(UInt8(8), UInt8(10)) # works - evaluates to true
isunsigned(UInt8(8), UInt16(10)) # method error
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching isunsigned(::UInt8, ::UInt16)
Closest candidates are:
  isunsigned(::T, ::T) where T<:Unsigned at REPL[69]:1```
Both UInt8 and UInt16 are subtypes of Unsigned. Why does the function not work when different Unsigned values are passed?

elements.text: Hi. Why does this function not work when different UInts are passed?

isunsigned(x::T, y::T) where {T <: Unsigned} = (x isa Unsigned) && (y isa Unsigned)
isunsigned(UInt8(8), UInt8(10)) # works - evaluates to true
isunsigned(UInt8(8), UInt16(10)) # method error
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching isunsigned(::UInt8, ::UInt16)
Closest candidates are:
  isunsigned(::T, ::T) where T<:Unsigned at REPL[69]:1
Both UInt8 and UInt16 are subtypes of Unsigned. Why does the function not work when different Unsigned values are passed?

attachments.title: Compiler Explorer - C++ (x86-64 clang 11.0.1)
attachments.text: // uses 24 bytes starting at p by doing a 32-byte load from p-4. // Don't use this for the first vector of a page-aligned array __m256i unpack12to16(const char *p) { __m256i v = _mm256_loadu_si256( (const __m256i*)(p-4) ); // v= [ x J I H G F | E D C B A x ] where each letter is a 3-byte pair of two 12-bit fields const __m256i bytegrouping = _mm256_setr_epi8(4,5, 5,6, 7,8, 8,9, 10,11, 11,12, 13,14, 14,15, // low half uses last 12B 0,1, 1,2, 3,4, 4,5, 6, 7, 7, 8, 9,10, 10,11); // high half uses first 12B v = _mm256_shuffle_epi8(v, bytegrouping); // each 16-bit chunk has the bits it needs, but not in the right position // in each chunk of 8 nibbles (4 bytes): [ f e d c | d c b a ] __m256i hi = _mm256_srli_epi16(v, 4); // [ 0 f e d | xxxx ] __m256i lo = _mm256_and_si256(v, _mm256_set1_epi32(0x00000FFF)); // [ 0000 | 0 c b a ] return _mm256_blend_epi16(lo, hi, 0b10101010); }
